docs.lead_paragraph: The rate of Alzheimer's disease and other dementias is falling in the United States and some other rich countries — good news about an epidemic that is still growing simply because more people are living to an old age, new studies show.

headline.main: Study: US Alzheimer's Rate Seems to Be Dropping
headline.print_headline: Study: US Alzheimer's Rate Seems to Be Dropping

docs.snippet: The rate of Alzheimer's disease and other dementias is falling in the United States and some other rich countries — good news about an epidemic that is still growing simply because more people are living to an old age, new studies show.

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans don’t trust government. Armed with data, a new generation of policy makers is trying to remedy that.

headline.main: The Quiet Movement to Make Government Fail Less Often
headline.print_headline: A Quiet Movement to Help Government Falter Less Often

docs.abstract: David Leonhardt The Upshot column; most Americans do not think of their government as particularly successful, but new generation of data-savvy policy makers and researchers has entered government and begun pushing it to do better; result is flowering of experiments to figure out what works and what does not.
docs.snippet: Americans don’t trust government. Armed with data, a new generation of policy makers is trying to remedy that.

docs.lead_paragraph: Assistance programs operating in states with their own insurance marketplaces helped more people than those in states relying on the federal exchange, a survey found.

headline.seo: Assisters Helped 10.6 Million With Coverage Under A.C.A.
headline.main: Groups Under Health Act Are Said to Aid Millions
headline.print_headline: Groups Under Health Act Are Said to Aid Millions

docs.abstract: Kaiser Family Foundation survey reports that more than 4,400 consumer assistance programs created under Affordable Care Act helped an estimated 10.6 million people explore their new heath insurance options and apply for coverage during the initial six-month enrollment period; survey finds that programs operating in states with their own online insurance market places got more funding and helped more people than those in states on federal exchange.
docs.snippet: Assistance programs operating in states with their own insurance marketplaces helped more people than those in states relying on the federal exchange, a survey found.

docs.lead_paragraph: New guidelines emphasize that employers cannot discriminate against workers because of past, present or future pregnancies.

headline.main: Equal Opportunity Employment Officials Take New Aim at Pregnancy Bias
headline.print_headline: Equal Opportunity Employment Officials Take New Aim at Pregnancy Bias

docs.abstract: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission issues new guidelines emphasizing that employers cannot discriminate against workers because of past, present or future pregnancies.
docs.snippet: New guidelines emphasize that employers cannot discriminate against workers because of past, present or future pregnancies.

docs.lead_paragraph: The free-standing emergency room, Lenox Hill HealthPlex, is part of a trend that provides acute care but also helps a hospital’s bottom line.

headline.main: An E.R., Not a Hospital, Is Set to Open at St. Vincent’s Site
headline.print_headline: E.R., Not a Hospital, Is Set to Open at St. Vincent’s Site

docs.abstract: North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System is opening free-standing emergency room in building that was once part of St Vincent's Hospital in West Village; ER, to be called Lenox Hill HealthPlex to denote its relationship with North Shore's hospital on the Upper East Side, is part of growing trend across country and has as much to do with a hospital's bottom line as providing acute care.
docs.snippet: The free-standing emergency room, Lenox Hill HealthPlex, is part of a trend that provides acute care but also helps a hospital’s bottom line.

docs.lead_paragraph: A favorite argument in favor of the health care law is that improving access to preventive care will lower medical costs over all. It probably won't.

headline.main: Why Improving Access to Health Care Does Not Save Money

docs.snippet: A favorite argument in favor of the health care law is that improving access to preventive care will lower medical costs over all. It probably won't.
